clinicalDescription: Overview: A condition (acute or chronic) in which the blood does not have enough oxygen (hypoxemic) or has too much carbon dioxide (hypercapnic). Causes include lung diseases (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), emphysema, cystic fibrosis, pneumonia, pulmonay embolism); nerve and muscle issues (spinal cord injuries, etc); injury to the chest; drug or alcohol overdose; obstruction; and inhalation injuries. Acute respiratory distress symdrome (ARDS) is a serious condition with low blood oxygen. Presentation: (different if low oxygen or high carbon dioxide) - shortness of breath, cyanotic skin, lips, fingernails, rapid breathing, confusion, can lose consciousness, and arrhythmias Assessment: physical exam, pulse oximetry, arterial blood gas (ABG), chest x-ray (CXR), electrocardiogram (EKG)Plan: Treat the cause of the respiratory failure. Oxygen therapy, breathing treatments, intubation (mechanical ventilation) or tracheostomy if needed, bronchoscopyPrognosis: Acute respiratory failure can be a medical emergency. Chronic respiratory failure symptoms are managed with treatment, and can cause long-term lung damage.
